questions.question: She may …………………….. his name.
questions.description: After modal auxiliary verbs, we use the infinitive without to. There is no –s in the third person singular.

questions.question: She ……………………….. speak English.
questions.description: Modal verbs have no –s in the third person singular.

questions.question: He ………………………….. do that.
questions.description: Modal auxiliary verbs make questions and negatives without do.

questions.question: You must …………………………. now.
questions.description: After modals, we use the infinitive without to.

questions.question: The walls ought to ………………………… one of these days.
questions.description: Passive infinitives can be used after modals.

questions.question: I really ……………………… to work hard in those days.
questions.description: The modal verb must does not have a past tense form. We use other verbs when necessary.

questions.question: You ………………………….. me you were coming.
questions.description: We can use have + past participle after a modal verb to express a past idea.

questions.question: ‘Suma hasn’t arrived yet.’ ‘She ……………………….. the train.’
questions.description:
We can use have + past participle after a modal verb to express a past idea.
Note that can is not used to talk about logical possibility.

questions.question: She …………………………. be in London or Paris.
questions.description: We do not use can in affirmative clauses to indicate logical possibility.

questions.question: Chennai …………………………. be very hot in March.
questions.description: We use can to talk about theoretical or habitual possibility.

questions.question: ‘Where is Janaki?’ ‘She ………………………… have gone swimming.’
questions.description: May and might are possible here. We do not use can in affirmative clauses to talk about logical possibility.

questions.question: Students ………………………….. use the staff car park.
questions.description: All of these expressions can be used to talk about prohibition.
